Description: Terracotta figure of Harpokrates. Harpokrates seated on the ground, his knees widespread, his feet close together. He is naked and holding a pot in his left arm, his right index finger is to his mouth. Except for a side-lock his head is shaven, and he wears a double crown. The back is plain, with a circular vent. Hollow and from a two-piece mould. Traces of white coating. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt. Top of crown broken and missing, right knee and stomach chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

British Museum GR 1973,0501.37 and 1973,0501.35 (Bailey 2008, no. 3061) are very similar, but not from the same mould. Similar parallels thought to be from Naukratis (Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no.1891-1908, E.4686); those dated to the Hellenistic/Roman period (Fjeldhagen 1995, no.5); and from a Graeco-Roman cemetery at Minshat Abu Omar in the Eastern Delta (Kroeper 1988, 35, pl. 3). Fjeldhagen, M. 1995, Catalogue Graeco-Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek, Copenhagen. Kroeper, K. 1988, in E.C.M. Van Den Brink (ed.), The archaeology of the Nile Delta, Amsterdam.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.098) (Phase 3)
